Talent Acquisition Specialist - manages the entire hiring process, from screening to contract.  Talent Marketing Specialist- develops the company's Employer Branding and Recruitment Marketing strategies. In charge of evolving recruitment, so the company can attract top talent. HRBP - Responsible for you from the moment your onboarding process ends. HR analytics - collects and analyzes HR data, and applies it to make recommendations related to recruitment, retention, and legal compliance. In smaller companies, one person can cover a few of these positions. But these are DIFFERENT positions.  HR is NOT recruitment. Second, 1 out of 5 people is a software developer! Well, I was amazed by this one. I would think that SW people who are in high demand would be the last to get fired. I can explain it with 2 ideas - first, most of them are juniors /from small startups that had to close, second, AdviceMe's branding was especially oriented for tech people. Another interesting piece of data- 80% of the people who asked for our advice had at least an undergrad degree. The higher education was the fewer people there were. name: Beth Seidenberg
headline: Managing Director at Westlake Village BioPartners & General Partner at Kleiner Perkins
about: Beth has medicine in her blood. From standing on a stool as a child watching her father conducting heart surgery, to her groundbreaking work developing new treatments for diseases as diverse as AIDS and arthritis, Beth has applied her medical expertise to the venture capital world. Her energy and attention to detail coupled with her drive to improve human health prove valuable assets in the complex and multifaceted world of being a venture capitalist.Looking ahead, Beth’s vision for Westlake Village BioPartners is to become one of the top biotech investors in the country and establish Los Angeles as a major biotech hub.

There was an article about "Zoom etiquette" posted here that, quite frankly, REALLY rubs me the wrong way. It calls out things like "must turn on camera", "being on time is already considered late (???)", etc.  How about this: We're all at home, with kids, pets, background noises, trying to work, eat, sleep, and most of all, SURVIVE through a global pandemic. Worry less about "Zoom etiquette" and more about how your peers, co-workers and fellow humans are doing. Better yet, ask them. It will brighten their day, and yours. Instead of worrying about etiquette: embrace empathy, kindness and forgiveness for Zoom. If you don't feel like the world is ready to see you, for whatever reason, turn the camera off. If you have pets and kids in the background, we love to see them!! If there's noise, it's OK, we'll mute you and laugh about it :).  For the record, I impress these exact same things to the folks in my organization. So please. Let's be kind and patient with each other during these unprecedented times. We're all trying, and not everyone is doing well. The last thing we need to do is hold people accountable for being 2 minutes late to a Zoom meeting, or some other silly thing. Give them a smile and some warm words instead. #dobetter   #empathy   #kindness   #humanity   #leadership

Some years ago, I was in a situation where I was being yelled at by a senior executive. It was incredibly tense,  stressful, and actually over something I wasn't even involved in - a complete case of bizarre mistaken identity. This wasn't the first time I had been disrespected in the workplace, but something about that day was different, because as soon as this person started yelling, I looked at them and said: "Please lower your voice". Stunned, they stopped for a second, then continued to yell for another several minutes. After they were out of breath, they waited for me to talk. When I said nothing, they asked what I had to say. My response was simply this: "I stopped paying attention when you started to raise your voice. The next conversation we'll have will be with HR in the room." And then I left.  They didn't get fired, but they never yelled again. Not at me, anyway. The moral of the story: "You're only a victim as long as you allow yourself to be one" #leadership   #dobetter   #kindness   #zerobullying

content:
During a 1:1 last week, someone asked me to list the top three traits that make a great manager and leader. While there are many things that make up a great leader, I found the exercise of ranking the top three thought-provoking - this is my list: 1) Practice humanity-first leadership. You can, and should, exceed at both delivery and empathy. They are never mutually exclusive, and equally important. 2) Earn trust through transparency. Don't lie to your employees. EVER. You will eventually be exposed. Be respectfully transparent to the highest extent possible. The trust broken when a leader is caught or exposed for having lied, especially in a public forum, is never ever regained. 3) Actively invest in people's careers. Know the difference between feedback and growth coaching, and how both are applied. Use feedback as teaching moments, not punitively, unless absolutely necessary. Coach your folks on how to grow and succeed, actively and passionately. Advocate for their success proactively, in terms of compensation and promotability. Show them you truly care when it matters most. [EDIT] I’ll add one more: 4) Provide recognition and gratitude. Sincere and genuine “thank you’s” are both free, as well as priceless. Those are my top 3 - what are yours?  #leadership   #dobetter

Lifetime advice from my mentor that has always served me well:  You will encounter a dead-end position, a toxic manager, a critically broken organization, a floundering company (or sometimes a combination of all these things). The litmus test for abandoning ship is very simple:  1) The smartest and most senior people are leaving  2) The work and mission become about “how do we survive” instead of “how do we grow” 3) Hiring stops and backfills/attrition are not honored 4) Management becomes adversarial, starts breaking promises, changes messaging and stops being transparent. 5) Budgets get slashed Any one of these issues in and of itself is cause for concern. Two or more are clear guidance towards the exit sign. Last, and perhaps most important:  Stop romanticizing the workplace in a situation like this. Capitalism and business are a clinical game, not a fairy tale. The only things you get by holding on to hollow words and platitudes instead of evaluating hard data and listening to your gut and instincts are career setbacks, money lost, emotional damage and a bag full of empty promises.  #commonsense   #wisdom   #lifelesson

Dear recruiters, I know you have an extremely difficult job. The hiring market is white hot and getting worse (better, for candidates) by the hour. We all get pinged repeatedly, daily. I mostly don't mind. However, here are a few rules you should follow to help you improve your contact:hire ratio and not turn candidates off to your pitch: 1) Don't email candidates at work. Just don't. It's incredibly unprofessional.If you email me at work (and I get these daily), you are guaranteed to be blocked and added to Junk Mail. 2) Take the time to read candidate profiles to see where their interests lie, where they are in their careers, and how your role would help them get ahead. Emailing blindly for stuff that clearly doesn't fit just turns candidates off.   3) Don't force a fit. Ever. For any reason. Don't lie. Be as transparent as possible about the opportunity. You're talking to a highly educated populous with access to data and inside company networks that you don't have. We're not dumb and we do our own research. Start with this. Adhere to integrity and first principles. Candidates actually like hearing from you about opportunities they may not otherwise have. What they don't like is to be pestered, intruded upon, and lied to. Thank you for considering the feedback.

name: Sarah Kauss
headline: Founder & Executive Chairwoman at S'well
about: Sarah is a consumer products leader with a track record in launching companies, building multi-million dollar successful brands, and assembling high-performance senior leadership teams. She is a successful global entrepreneur, product design expert and has deep experience in partnering with multinational corporations to become more sustainable and meet environmental goals. Sarah held the position of CEO of S’well for ten years: bootstrapping with $30k of her savings to reach over $100M in revenue. During this time, Sarah created a new category and well-loved brand, helping to make sustainability more mainstream. An early advocate of the importance of ESG, Environmental, Social and Governance, in business, Sarah integrated values and impact within S’well from the start. Today, S'well is a Certified B Corp with a wide range of products that has helped displace more than 4 billion single-use plastic bottles. Prior to S’well, Sarah was an international real estate developer with a publicly-traded real estate equity investment trust where she spent six years with increasing responsibility leading large international collaborations and partnerships. Sarah started her career in public accounting with EY (formerly Ernst & Young), as a Certified Public Accountant, working in both tax consulting and the auditing function. She provided professional services to public and privately held companies in the technology, consumer products and media sectors. Sarah regularly shares her lessons learned and most important entrepreneurial moments with the press, including Inc., Fortune, Forbes, Bloomberg, NPR and more. She has been recognized as a Fortune’s “40 Under 40” honoree, EY Entrepreneurial Winning Woman and awarded the Harvard Business School Club of New York's Entrepreneurship Award. Under Sarah’s leadership, S’well was named #1 Fastest-Growing, women-led company by the Women Presidents’ Organization, was honored with the Brand Design award by Inc. magazine and placement on the Inc. 500 List (top 100) of fastest-growing, privately-held companies. Sarah sits on the UNICEF USA New York Regional Board, is an Entrepreneur in Residence at Harvard Business School and a mentor in the Fortune-State Department Global Mentoring Program. Sarah is a member of the 2018 Class of Henry Crown Fellows and a member of the 2020 Class of Braddock Scholars within the Aspen Global Leadership Network at the Aspen Institute. She earned a BS in accounting from the University of Colorado, Boulder and an MBA from Harvard Business School.

I've been through that cycle. I learnt to build a thicker amour.  I'm strengthened in my value of sharing knowledge. I walk my own path. The biggest obstacle is not their hate. Or critiques. Please, please, PLEASE be thoughtful in your connection requests and personalize!
